captions.text:
Hi, I'm Mindy from
Cute Girls Hairstyles,

and this morning I'm
going to show you

a hairdo that I'm calling
Same-Side Lace Braid.

Now, you might also
notice that I have bangs.

So my husband went
out of town last week,

and while he was away I woke
up one morning and was like,

I think I want bangs, and
shwoop, cut them myself.
And here they are.

So we're kind of learning
and retraining my hair.
But let's do this one.

This is a hairdo I
found on Pinterest.

Now, for those of you who
aren't familiar with Pinterest,

it's like the latest
social media website.

And it is crazy fun, and
I'm totally addicted.

I will be doing
a video, probably

I'll get it up tomorrow
or the next day,

on how to use Pinterest, and
explaining a little bit more

about it, and how you
can find me on Pinterest.

But this is an idea
I got off Pinterest.

And when you see
what Pinterest is you
will all be as addicted as I am.

So I started by just
straightening her hair,
and I parted it to the left.

Of course you can part
it on either side.

I'm going to just start by doing
just a regular French braid.

So I'm going to pick
up some hair in front

and divide it into
three sections

and start a regular
French braid.

Now, I am going to only
pick up from the top.

I'm not going to pick
up from the bottom
on this French braid.

So it's a one sided, which
makes it the Lace Braid.

I'm going to pick up a
little strand of hair
and add it into the top.

And the braid is going to
kind of go on a diagonal
down like that.

Just so that's kind of
where we're heading with it.

So I'm going to pick up
another little piece of hair,

add it into the top strand,
and then braid it in.
Pick up a piece of hair.

Now, I kind of want to be able
to see the strands I'm pulling,

so I'm trying not to pull
like too chunky of pieces.
So braid it in.

Like you'll notice I'm just
picking up a little piece

because I kind of
want that chunky

look where you can
see the stranding.

And as I'm going down
I'm going obviously away

from her part line, which means
I am letting her hair fall more
and more.

Like that piece I'm adding in
is becoming longer and longer
before I add it in.

Now, when I get to about
here I'm going to go ahead,

I think I'm going
to be done, and just
finish it off by braiding it.

And then when I get
down a little ways

I'm going to go back and
just loosen the braid.

OK, so the easiest way-- I
have a tendency to braid tight.

So I have to kind of remind
myself, try to braid lose,
braid lose.
Go back in.

Kind of just give it like little
tugs to let that braid loosen.
And then elastic please.

I'm going to add in just
a clear elastic that

matches her that will fade
in and match her hair.
And we're done.

And then if you
want afterwards you

can go back in and
loosen some more.
So those bumps really pop out.
And there you go.
Really fun.
Easy idea.

And I think this one you
could use on any age.

In fact, I would definitely
do this on my own hair.
I think it's so cute.
And there you go.

comments.author: LyricsMaster

comments.text:
Oh, and also be sure to get a different color of elastic than clear! They 
show up like a glowing neon blob even in red hair. My hair's a little dark 
(for a redhead), so I use brown elastics. You'll definitely need black 
ones.
comments.author: TengwarSoup

comments.text:
With very dark colored or curly/wavy/thick hair, a lot of stuff doesn't 
show up too well. This will probably work, provided you take larger chunks 
of hair than they did. If your hair is pin-straight, you probably don't 
even need to do that. I have really thick, wavy hair, so I almost always 
switch a french braid to a dutch braid so I can see it. (and I find the 
dutch braid easier to do.) You'll just have to fiddle around with 
hairstyles like this for a while before you can tell!
comments.author: TengwarSoup
